item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: kitor
item.description:
“Classic” Xbox version had frame rate problems - but it was (i think) one of the best-looking titles released for that console. In fact, my first completed append to HL2 was on Xbox. I still remember Ravenholm, when i had damaged one of pad’s analogs.

Now I’m using modified (usb, just changed plug and installed XBCD) Xbox Controller ‘S’ with my PC. Don’t know why, but the gameplay is sightly better for me with this pad.

Read full topic

item.source: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2

item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: bray32641
item.description:
I believe you are mistaken about HL2 for Xbox1 yes the graphics and lighting are duller due to the developers conforming it to the Xbox1’s Coppermine Pentium 3 and Nvidea X3 GPU. The only thing missing in the game is objects in the background like buildings, this only happens with exteriors or out doors. This is because of Xbox1’s limited RAM of about 64 megs, as far as every thing else goes, all the levels are there from the PC and all the same content is there too. I can’t remember witch Xbox Magazine, it was the XBM before HL2 launched for Xbox1. Valve Stated that nothing was missing from the Xbox version of HL2. I deal with the other short comings but the framrate dipping while the full on physics engine gets hammered by a ton of particals in the background during firefights hinders the game a little for me. But Im still impressed with how well the rest of the game runs especially since the minimum system requirement is 1500 Mhz 256 MBs of Ram, The Xbox Runs it well on a scale from 1 to 10 that being a 6 for the Xbox. Not bad for an Xbox that is only 733 Mhz, 64 MB of RAM. Don’t knock a good contender!!!

Read full topic

item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: Crikulus
item.description:
JohnKiller118:

In Half-Life 1 on the PC, the computer monitor was right in my face, since I couldn’t just lay on the couch and play. While playing “On a Rail”, I fucking DUCKED in my chair when I was approaching one of those rail road signs!
Mind you, this is Half-Life 1… on the fucking GoldSrc engine… where everything looked like shit.
Now THAT’S immersion!

This is one of the things I really enjoy more on PC games, is that the screen is closer, and TVs just don’t beat computer LCDs, I never liked TV screens much.

Read full topic

item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: Grey_Acumen
item.description:
JCH152:

I’ve heard and e-mailed Gabe Newell about upgrading Half-Life 2 to Orange Box on PC but all he said was “Yes, we’re going to do that sometime, I don’t know when though.”

Most likely it’ll be during or after the release of Episode 3. Provided they don’t upgrade the Orange Source Engine too much for it. Then again, maybe they’ll release a full out “UPGRADE EVERYTHING” that will upgrade HL2 - Ep2 to whatever Engine Ep3 is running on.

I just wish it’d be possible that the mods could benefit from the upgrades without having to completely recompile them, but I guess that’d be asking way too much.

Read full topic

item.source: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2

item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: Skilgannon
item.description:
Hi, been lurking a couple of weeks now since I found out about this. I won’t gush like a noob, so on topic.

I was given the original Xbox version of HL2 for my 15th back in '05, and having since played the PC version, I can say that the console version differs majorly in a few areas. I will list the differences.

XBox HL2:

Pros: Well thought out inventory system for the controller, big combine walls make huge creaking, grinding and crushing noises, ummmm…?

Cons: Frequent load points, redesigned levels, removed content, lower-res textures, lower poly count models, less effects, looks overall quite rough, no modding, slow and stodgy looking controls, where are the headcrab’s teeth?

PC HL2:

Pros: Modding, looks awesome (textures, models etc), larger levels, less load points, extra content, keyboard and mouse combo, more effects.

Cons: Big combine walls make no noise, still no headcrab teeth, ummmm…?

So yes, basically, PC HL2 > Xbox HL2.

Read full topic
item.source: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2

item.description:
I’ve recently played the xbox1 version of hl2 and it totally sucks, some parts they added these completely random rooms out of nowhere, for example when you see the headcrab shells for the first time (right before the airboat) you are in a completely destroyed place and then boom you’re in a room with a light on top. Doesn’t make any sense to me.

item.title: Original xbox port vs pc half life 2
item.dc:creator: JohnKiller118
item.description:
Door:

This is why the Novint Falcon is useful for single-player Source games.
I should’ve entered that competition on the Steam forums to win one… I would have beaten that employee’s ass.

For me, it has to be on the PC. The free updates and nicer graphics are a winner.

Also, why are we even discussing this?

I agree. When comes ot Valve games, it’s PC>All else. I wouldn’t say PC>All else overall (we have our own opinons), but with the Source engine’s modding community, it’s no contest for which version of a Valve game you need to get.

…unless you have console only frineds and want to play L4D2 with them.
